node.title: Error: The component setup status (1) is less than the required status (2)
node.bodyText:
Hey. @joshuahansel I think there're are unknown bugs in the new Component I've created. The general structure is like HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase. But I don't know where is the bug. My present purpose is to calculate the lateral flow between two FlowChannel1Phases. I only add the lateral equation in the new Component.(Should I rewrite the basic fluid equations in my new Component?). The input file is:
T_in = 300.         # K
m_dot_in = 1e-4     # kg/s
press = 1e5         # Pa

[GlobalParams]
  initial_p = ${press}
  initial_vel = 0
  initial_T = ${T_in}

  rdg_slope_reconstruction = full
  closures = simple_closures
  fp = he
[]

[Modules/FluidProperties]
  [./he]
    type = IdealGasFluidProperties
    molar_mass = 4e-3
    gamma = 1.67
    k = 0.2556
    mu = 3.22639e-5
  [../]
[]

[Closures]
  [simple_closures]
    type = Closures1PhaseSimple
  []
[]

[Components]
  [./inlet1]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'core_chan1:in'
    m_dot = 0.6
    T = 300
  [../]
  [core_chan1]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'
    length = 10
    n_elems = 50
    A = 0.001
    D_h = 0.1333
    f = 1.6
  [../]
  [outlet1]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'core_chan1:out'
    p = 1e5
  [../]
  [./inlet2]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'core_chan2:in'
    m_dot = 1.2
    T = 300
  [../]
  [core_chan2]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0.5 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'
    length = 10
    n_elems = 50
    A = 0.002
    D_h = 0.2667
    f = 1.6
  [../]
  [outlet2]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'core_chan2:out'
    p = 1e5
  [../]
  [Gap]
    type = TwoChannelsModel
    current_flow_channel = core_chan1
    adjacent_flow_channel = core_chan2
    fp = he
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  start_time = 0
  end_time = 2
  dt = 0.1

  line_search = basic
  solve_type = NEWTON

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  nl_max_its = 5
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]


And the error says:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "core_chan2", of type "FlowChannel1Phase".

core_chan2: The component setup status (1) is less than the required status (2)

I don't know why there's something wrong with the core_chan2. I didn't change anything about the FlowChannel1Phase
I can show the source code if necessary.
Ethan

Hi Ethan,
This error message isn't very useful - it needs to tell you what those numbers (1 and 2) mean 🤦
So components have a number of methods that get called in order; see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Components/index.html. This "setup status" indicates which of these methods have already been called. Sometimes we want to check that we've already called some of these methods before doing something (else we could get garbage or segfaults, etc.). The error comes from lines like
checkSetupStatus(MESH_PREPARED);

Can you get a stacktrace (run in debug mode)?
And I'm happy to look at your component code too, though it appears the error message must be indirect from your component, since it comes from a FlowChannel1Phase.

In your UO's header, you should have:
const MaterialProperty<RealVectorValue> & _adjacent_grad_rhoa_coupled;

and in your UO initializer list:
_adjacent_grad_rhoa_coupled(getMaterialProperty<RealVectorValue>("_adjacent_grad_rhoa_coupled")),

Do you have this?
Oh, I got the data type wrong. Thank you. I know where the problem is.

node.title: Surface Tension Force
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
Has anyone tried to add the surface tension force to the Navier-Stokes equation using Cahn-Hilliard equation? Is there any kernel for that which could be helpful?
Thanks,
Ali

hi, I am also studing this problem about coupling INS eqution with  CH equation.
In the terms of program , the moose module phase-field and navier-stokes has many C.file can be used. we can make a new app and then apply these program according to the eqution. But the surface tension term need to be written by yourself to add to the INS module.
However, I found that when introducing the surface tension, the bubble in the liquid closed square cavity will shrinke rately. this is unphysical.

Thank you for your reply. Shrinking is a common problem in these kind of simulations and it is not out of ordinary. Maybe you used non-conserved advection term for the CH equation. By the way, did you develop your custom kernel for the surface tension force in INS?
yes, i add surface tension term fs=\mu\nabla\fai to the INS kernel like the moose file INSMomentumBase.C

Can you tell me the exact equations that you used for surface tension and free energy? By the way, did you add your custom kernel to your github?
Thanks,
Ali

hi, I am also studing this problem about coupling INS eqution with CH equation.
In the terms of program , the moose module phase-field and navier-stokes has many C.file can be used. we can make a new app and then apply these program according to the eqution. But the surface tension term need to be written by yourself to add to the INS module.
However, I found that when introducing the surface tension, the bubble in the liquid closed square cavity will shrinke rately. this is unphysical.

Hello,
Did you also implement the wetting boundary condition? I am also struggling in this and appreciate it if you can help me in it.
Regards,
Ali

This problem will be considered later. Now, I want to solve the surface tension firstly. In my current simulation, the NuumannBC of chemical potential is used， simply assuming that the contact angel is 90°.
Thank you. Great job there!

In my project, the Navier-Stokes-Cahn-Hilliard Equations in MOOSE is based on  the following programs:

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Phase_Field_Equations.html
Peterson, J. W., Lindsay, A. D., & Kong, F. (2018). Overview of the incompressible Navier–Stokes simulation capabilities in the MOOSE framework. Advances in Engineering Software, 119(February), 68–92. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.advengsoft.2018.02.004

node.title: How to mix fluids in the TH Module Single-Phase-Flow tutorial?
node.bodyText:
Greetings All,
I would like to use the 1-D single-phase-flow structure as the basic structure to implement graphite dust motion with the helium gas.
I understand that it has been made clearly that the single-phase-flow doesn't support mixing fluids, so my questions are:

Is there a way to manipulate the code to make it support the mix of the fluids? (The dust shall flow with the helium gas, thus it will still be a single phase flow)
Is this a situation where the Multi-App functionalities jump in?
Is there a better module to solve this issue without taking too much computational power?

Thank you so much!

Hello

yes. This will become a scalar transport problem. We do not support this right now in THM (@joshuahansel for fact-checking me) but I m very confident it's not difficult to add.
You may elect to use MultiApps. The main reason for that is to limit the number of variables in a single solve, especially when the transported species does not influence the velocity distribution of the main fluid.
we have similar problematics with the Navier Stokes module (transporting neutron precursors in molten salt reactor) and  in the future in the scalar transport module (this module will serve, in the future, as a base for tritium transport in the open-source TMAP8). If your system is small you can try finite volume Navier Stokes.

Guillaume
Fact-check returns TRUE (No scalar transport currently in THM).

Note that we do have the following fluid properties formulation for arbitrary mixtures of gases: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/IdealRealGasMixtureFluidProperties.html. There are alternative formulations out there.
After this piece, you can decide on what PDEs you want to be solving. It's possible that maybe you'll just be able to add an equation or two alongside the ones in FlowChannel1Phase.
Thank you so much for all these useful information! I am still new to Moose, how exactly do I add equations in FlowChannel1Phase?

I'd just clarify that this wouldn't be "in FlowChannel1Phase", but would just be objects that you add in your input file alongside it.
As far as how to add equations, that's a pretty broad topic - you'll probably need to go through at least some tutorials: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html. But the residual objects that will be relevant will be

Kernels: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Kernels/index.html
DGKernels: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/DGKernels/index.html (depending on what spatial discretization you choose)
BCs: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/BCs/index.html

But first, let us know which equations you want to solve so that we can check if there is something existing that you can use.

Hello Joshua,
I might have gotten it wrong to begin with. Instead of mixing two types of fluids together, I actually want to use the calculated velocity (u) to couple with my source terms (graphite dust, fission products, and so on). By starting with the customized 1-D diffusion equation:
partial_f(x,t) /partial_t = u* partial_f(x,t) /partial_x + source, where f(x,t) could be graphite dust or fission products and u is the calculated velocity from single-phase-flow.
Is there something existing that can help me with this?
Yifan

Ok, that seems like it shouldn't be too bad then. There's nothing in the TH module to solve this equation (and I don't think the scalar transport module would help you here yet), but I think it would be easy enough to implement - just need a kernel for a product of a variable and a gradient of another variable. There might be such a kernel already.

I tried to use the existing kernels (ConservativeAdvection) which seems to get the job done. However, since the velocity is not from the input parameters, but a calculated output instead. It gives me the error message that "coupled variable 'vel' was not found", what shall I do in this case?
you can define an auxvariable vel and initialize it to the value you want.

While FlowChannel1Phase should give you a variable called vel, I see that ConservativeAdvection is requesting a vector variable, whereas vel is scalar (since it's 1-D). So you would need an aux kernel that takes vel and multiplies it by a vector (your normalized orientation vector of FlowChannel1Phase. The caution here is that you will lose the automatic differentiation when involving aux kernels, so your convergence may suffer. I'd recommend a kernel that uses a scalar vel directly. If one does not exist, you could write one (for now, you could copy and paste ConservativeAdvection and then make the changes there):
_velocity[_qp]

goes to
_vel[_qp] * _orientation
I located the ConservativeAdvection. But once I clicked in, there are just some input files. How can I change the source file for ConservativeAdvection as you described above?

ConservativeAdvectionScalar_h.txt
ConservativeAdvectionScalar_C.txt
Rename these two files to ConservativeAdvectionScalar.h and ConservativeAdvectionScalar.C, respectively, and then put them into framework/include/kernels and framework/src/kernels, respectively. Recompile your executable and try it out.

I am trying to add my own AuxKernel object called DustConvectionAux to the TH tutorial.
I create DustConvectionAux.h and DustConvectionAux.C, put them in ./modules/thermal_hydralics/include/auxkernel and ./modules/thermal_hydralics/src/auxkernel respectively. I register it to the ThermalHydraulicsApp as well, but it still complains that DustConvectionAux is not registered.
I also tried to register it in my src/base/ThermalHydraulicsAppApp.C file, still not working.
It can be complied just fine.
Any idea about how to fix this?

node.title: Failed Installation of Libmesh on HPC Cluster
node.bodyText:
For some reason, I have to install an old version of MOOSE on the HPC cluster (git checkout 34fb8fa). However, I met an error when running update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh. The error is /usr/bin/ld: cannot find -ludev. I've checked similar discussions #18868 to run the command git submodule sync in the Libmesh submodule. However, it did not work on my end. Modules I loaded on HPC clusters are:

module load python/2.7.16

module load libevent/2.1.8
module load numactl/2.0.12

I attached a snapshot of the error I met below:

I would appreciate it if any experts could help me have a look at it. Thank you in advance.

Does this fix it?
https://forum.qt.io/topic/60107/cannot-find-ludev
Thank you for your suggestion. I do not have permission to run sudo on the HPC cluster. I'll talk with the admin about it.

node.title: How to apply injection rate or flux to a domain instead of a boundary.
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Instead of applying an injection rate to a boundary/surface, I want to apply it to a small volume/domain within my model. Is this possible? How do I do it in MOOSE? I’m asking because, usually, BCs act on a surface/boundary and not a domain. Thank you.

Hello
You ll want to use a BodyForce or CoupledForce kernel to do that.
In what MOOSE type is the injection rate defined? A Function? A variable?
Guillaume
Is this an example of a use case for FunctionDiracSource https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/dirackernels/FunctionDiracSource.html?
For a point source this would work yes
link is fixed now

node.title: Steady Calculation in THM
node.bodyText:
@joshuahansel I didn't add time term in the adding equation. And I prepare to write a steady input file to test the new Component. When I change the type of the Excutioner into Steady in 1D_flow_channel.i.
The terminal says:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "THM:problem", of type "THMProblem".

Vector tag 'TIME' does not exist.

This may occur if you have a TimeKernel in your problem but did not specify a transient executioner.

So does THM has the ability to perform steady-state calculation? If so, how can I run a steady test?
Ethan

Hi Ethan,
This is because you have component(s) that add a time kernel (no matter what executioner you select). We find that actually doing a Steady calculation for flow equations is rarely successful due to nonlinear convergence difficulties; instead, we just run a transient to steady conditions. If you just have heat conduction, it should be fine though. If you really want to try, you can comment out the time kernels in the components that you use.
I see. Thank you:D
Hello @GiudGiud , do you have any idea? Thanks.

Hello
The mesh must be different in some way.
Could you please upload the mesh in a github repo?
Downloading zip files is frowned upon
Guillaume

I think the issue is that the mesh is being detected as a 3D mesh when it s really 1D.
I m not sure what you can do in gmsh to make it more 1D.
Maybe there's a number you can change in the .msh file??
Otherwise, more hacky approaches:
Maybe make X and Y equal to 0. Maybe use only the X axis instead of the Z axis for the 1D mesh.

You can transfer from a 1D mesh to a 3D model with no problem.
You dont need both meshes to be 3D.
For transfers? Any transfer will behave as expected. ShapeEvaluation or NearestNode are likely the best choices for it
For making the mesh 1D I have no idea. You should try the options I offered. You can always translate the mesh in MOOSE using a TransformGenerator

node.title: Question about setting the specific initial condition in the MOOSE simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have a question about setting the initial condition in MOOSE simulation.
I want to set the initial condition as the following shape, which is inside the red dotted line. How can I get its concentration from the files and put it in the new simulation? Can anyone give me some advice?

Thank you very much.
Best,

Hello
so you have this profile in a file? What kind of file? Exodus or CSV we can use SolutionUserObject or PropertyReadFile respectively
Guillaume
it is Exodus. But I also need to cut the model, only use the area inside the red-dotted line, how to realize it?

You can use a ParsedSubdomainGenerator to set subdomains along straight lines like this
Then you can block restrict the setting of the initial conditions

So, do I need to change the [Mesh] block? I am a little bit confused....
I attached my files here, could you have a look at it? How to load the data?
Also, I converted the Exodus file to cvs file, and I also attached here.
df_0d6_t_1_135.csv
df0d6_t_1_R_txt.txt

You can add another generator in the Mesh block to create that new subdomain.
If you have an exodus file with the data please have a look at the SolutionUserObject.
If the element ids aren’t exactly the same in your file and the new simulation this might not work btw. Please let us know once you’ve set it up

I did not load the shape successfully...
Since what I want to do is to add a perturbation to my simulation at the beginning, can I instead use this 'noise' function as the perturbation in my simulation?

Hi,
Do you know what is source_nodal?

Also, If I have 2 variables, how should I use 'SolutionUserObject' to read them? I only find how to read one variable from the examples.
Thank you.
Best,

Hello
Which input file is this from?
Also you should paste text instead of screenshots.
Guillaume

From SolutionUserObject website
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobject/SolutionUserObject.html
this is the name of the variable in the solution file. If you navigate to the test/tests/auxkernels/solution_aux folder and open the exodus file you ll see that variable.
Ok, so the source_nodal is only a name for one variable? How can I read two variables?

node.title: moose function
node.bodyText:
Hi,
May I ask a general question about the moose.
If now considering a problem between a 1D model 2D model, what is the function for a point.
Thanks very much.
Regards,
Jerry

Hello
You can use the positions attribute of the MultiApp to translate the the app's frame of reference if they are not well aligned.
If you are transferring a field/ a variable's value I would just use a MultiAppNearestNodeTransfer
Guillaume

You can use positions. This has nothing to do with the mesh
Please just try it
no you cant ignore the relative positions of systems. They need to match for the transfer to understand how to map values. This is what the positions argument of multiapps is for.
It depends what you're doing. You can transfer a single variable value, an entire field, etc.
You just need to pick the right transfer.

Please see this tutorial
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/presentation/index.html#/

node.title: Auxkernel or Postprocessor to change TimeStepper
node.bodyText:
Hello, I would like to change the dt value back to the minimum when a certain auxkernel changes the x position in the function. I have the following auxkernel:
[AuxKernels]
  [./add_material_in_the_ellipsoid]
    type = FunctionPathEllipsoidAux
    variable = level_set_var
    rx = 0.0018
    ry = 0.0015
    rz = 0.0015
    init_x_coords = '0.010 0.190 0.010'
    init_y_coords = '0.04175 0.04725 0.05275'
    init_z_coords = '0.016 0.016 0.016'
    temperature_pp = interpass_max_temp
    single_scan_length = '0.015 0.180 0.180'
    threshold_temperature = 320
    velocity = '0.007 -0.007 0.007'
  [../]
[]

and the following TimeStepper:

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    growth_factor = 30
    cutback_factor = 0.03
    linear_iteration_ratio = 45
    optimal_iterations = 3 #12
    iteration_window = 1
    dt = 0.3
  [../]

so at some point the dt increases to 9 and I would like to reduce it to 0.3 when the 'init_x_coords' in the auxkernel changes from 0.010 to 0.190. Is there any way of doing this?
My problem is that when the dt is 9 and I want it to change to 0.3, it does one step more with dt=9 than desired and the whole simulation is wrong, as it needs to come back to 0.3 just the step before it changes to 0.190 the init_x_coords.
Another possibility that I was thinking is to change the dt when a certain postprocessor reaches a threshold temperature. Is this possible? I have a postprocessor that calculates the maximum temperature in the simulation and maybe I could use it to change the TimeStepper when it reaches 320K let's say. This is the postprocessor:
[./interpass_max_temp]
type = NodalExtremeValue
variable = temp
value_type = max
[../]
Thank you in advance for your help

Hello
You ll want to use the timestep_limiting_postprocessor option
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/timesteppers/IterationAdaptiveDT.html
The postprocessor should be a class derived from ElementPostprocessor and it examines the value of the aux variable everywhere to determine its own value.
The value of the postprocessor is then the limiting time step
OR
You use the NodalExtremeValue to get the max of the field, and a ParsedPostprocessor to have some logic like:
if (interpass_max_temp > 0.019, 0.3, 100000)
in the function parameter
Guillaume
Guillaume

Thank you for your reply! I do not really understand the timestep_limiting_postprocessor option. Is it possible to tell to the TimeStepper that it has to be 0.3 when the max temperature in the simulation is less than 400K with this option?

yes.
Use a ParsedPostprocessor as the limiting postprocessor and for the function to parse:
if (interpass_max_temp <400, 0.3, 1e6) # 1e6 means no limit
Perfect, got it, thank you so much! :) Now it is working correctly
